articles.title: Hurricane Victims Could Lose Motel Rooms
articles.summary: Families displaced by Helene are bracing for another impact in Spartanburg County. The winter weather is coming in and Helene's impact is expected to be worse this time around. The storm is predicted to last for a few days.

articles.title: Researcher breaks down how climate change is impacting the Great Lakes
articles.summary: Dr. Kevin Strychar says the Great Lakes have been warming since the 1970s, creating a warmer climate. The Great Lakes are also seeing less ice coverage, which enables more time for moisture to evaporate into the atmosphere, which in turn powers more lake-effect snow.

articles.title: LA wildfires blaze on: A grim glimpse into climate-driven extremes
articles.summary: Scientists warn of climate-fuelled weather extremes that are likely to escalate further as global temperatures continue to climb. For California, scientists consider fire to be a yearlong risk. The western US state has seen increasingly massive conflagrations in recent years, with more acreage burned amid drying conditions and shifting weather trends.

articles.title: Call to integrate green tech into road construction
articles.author: Jamil Mirza
articles.summary: The challenges posed by climate change were highlighted during the inauguration of "Pakistan's first green road" at Fatima Jinnah Women University (FJWU) in Rawalpindi. The event also saw the participation of the ambassadors of Azerbaijan and Rwanda. Pakistan has suffered losses exceeding $3 billion due to climate change.

articles.title: You Know Who Else Blamed a Major Fire on a Global Conspiracy of His Political Enemies?
articles.author: Ben Mathis-Lilley
articles.summary: Alex Jones, a conspiracy theorist, wrote on Twitter that the ongoing Los Angeles wildfires have been engineered by 'globalists' in order to 'deindustrialize' the United States. Elon Musk, who is living on the incoming president's property, saw the post and liked it. In the past, Jones has explained that 'Jewish mafia' figures like George Soros are a key part of the 'globalist' alliance.

articles.title: Heatwave conditions scorching vast swathe of Australia
articles.author: Savannah Meacham
articles.summary: "It's not a sign to let our guard down as we all know how bushfire-prone Australia can be in the summer period," Ms Bradbury said. "With moderate to high we're still below warning level but it's still a warning level.

articles.title: Earth records hottest year ever in 2024 and the jump was so big it breached a key threshold
articles.author: The Associated Press
articles.summary: Earth recorded its hottest year ever in 2024. Last year's global average temperature easily passed 2023's. It's the first time any year passed the 1.5 degrees Celsius threshold. The last 10 years are the 10 hottest on record and likely the hottest in 125,000 years.

articles.title: It's official, La Nina is here and is expected to stay for the rest of winter
articles.author: Amber Wheeler
articles.summary: La Nina is the cool phase of the EL Nino Southern Oscillation (ENSO) climate pattern. It's expected to persist through winter of '25. Sea surface temperature anomalies are expected to warm in the spring. There is no strong signal for El Nino to return anytime soon.

articles.title: 2024: Warmest year on record at Baker City Airport
articles.author: Jayson Jacoby
articles.summary: 2024 was the warmest calendar year on record at the Baker City Airport. It was driven by record-breaking heat waves during the summer and an abnormally balmy December at the airport's weather station. It's the third warmest year ever recorded.

articles.title: Scientists drill nearly 2 miles down to pull 1.2 million-year-old ice core from Antarctic
articles.author: The Associated Press
articles.summary: Analysis of the ancient ice core is expected to show how Earth's atmosphere and climate have evolved. It should provide insight into how Ice Age cycles have changed. It may help in understanding how atmospheric carbon changed climate, they say. Thanks to the ice core, they will be able to do that.

articles.title: Stay Off Local Ice – Unsafe Conditions Highlighted by Fire and Rescue Officials
articles.author: Uriah Kiser
articles.summary: Prince William County Fire and Rescue System warns residents to stay off naturally occurring ice on local waters. Ice in this area is prone to cracks, instability, and variability due to fluctuating temperatures, moving water, and wildlife activity. Hypothermia can occur in less than 10 minutes in icy waters.

articles.title: Ancient kangaroo teeth hold clues to the role of climate change in ancient extinction
articles.summary: In a mass extinction event some 40,000 years ago, Australia lost 90% of its large species. New research suggests climate change played a much smaller role than once thought, though not all agree. On NPR, KPBX plays KPBZ 90.3 PRX Remix, and KSFC plays KSFC 91.9.

articles.title: In Unalaska, citizen scientists help document largest single-species wildlife die-off ever recorded
articles.author: Sofia Stuart-Rasi
articles.summary: Megan Dean was counting birds in Iliuliuk Bay on Front Beach in Unalaska. She was part of the Audubon Society's 32nd Christmas Bird Count. The largest bird populations in the 2024 count were black scoters, harlequin ducks, glaucous-winged gulls and bald eagles. Not a single common murre was spotted in the count. In 2009, locals counted more than 4,000 of them. In 2014, a catastrophic marine heatwave struck and their numbers started plummeting. Scientists linked the heatwave to human-caused climate change.

articles.title: The California fires are not climate
articles.author: Christina Norman
articles.summary: The Pacific Palisades fire is being fueled by Santa Ana winds stoked by hurricane-force wind gusts. The majority of fires in Southern California that occurred between 1948 and 2018 had a human ignition source. Only 5-20% of the variation in area burned during winter is explained by air temperature.

articles.title: California wildfires: Why 'hydroclimate whiplash' to blame for deadly blaze
articles.author: Studyfinds Staff
articles.summary: There is a dramatic swing between weather extremes known as 'hydroclimate whiplash' that is becoming more common worldwide due to climate change. Los Angeles experienced two extremely wet winters in 2024 and a dry start to the 2025 rainy season. The result was Tinder-dry vegetation that has fueled a series of devastating wildfires.

articles.title: Topsham hopes to adopt updated Climate Action Plan
articles.author: Paul Bagnall
articles.summary: Topsham is updating its decade-old Climate Action Plan. The plan originally focused on greenhouse gas emissions and actions to limit them, but it is now refocusing on multiple aspects of climate-related impacts on Topsham. The town received a $50,000 community action grant from the Community Resiliency Partnership through Gov. Janet Mills' Office of Policy, Innovation and the Future in October. F.B. Environmental Associates will review the draft plan at 6:30 p.m. on Feb. 4 at the municipal building.

articles.title: It's now a La Niña winter, but it's a weak one. What to know about it in Arizona
articles.author: Hayleigh Evans
articles.summary: La Niña has officially arrived, but meteorologists are expecting a weaker-than-normal climatological event. La Niña winters tend to bring drier and warmer conditions to Arizona, but as sea surface temperatures barely meet the threshold, it may not have as much of an effect as in previous years. This winter Arizona has had above-average temperatures and no measurable rainfall since August 22.

articles.title: TRU Professor co-authors study into wildfires in Canada over recent decades
articles.author: Jeff Andreas
articles.summary: Dr. Mike Flannigan has co-authored a study on the growing impact of fires in Canada over recent decades. He is the scientific director of Thompson Rivers University's Institute for Wildfire Science, Adaptation and Resiliency. He worked with seven other researchers to explore why fires burned more severely in Canadian forests from 1981 to 2020 and how these patterns changed over time. Dry fuel significantly increased fire severity, climate change had the biggest impact on northeastern and northwestern Canada, and severe fires occurred more frequently in the summer. All 10 Canadian ecozones experienced more severe fires, affecting six per cent of areas.

articles.title: IN PHOTOS: Extreme weather conditions fuel LA wildfires; human-caused climate change may be responsible
articles.author: Raaina Jain
articles.summary: Extreme weather conditions created perfect conditions for the recent wildfires in southern California. Last year's El Nino weather system brought heavy rains that fuelled excessive vegetation growth in the first half of 2024. The second half of the year was marked by drought, setting the stage for "precipitation whiplash"

articles.title: Cape Fear schools preparing for winter weather arriving Friday
articles.author: Wway News
articles.summary: Bladen County schools will have an asynchronous remote learning day on Friday, January 10. New Hanover County Schools will be canceling all after-school events and practices scheduled for Friday. Calvary Christian School will be closing after the end of the school day. Pender County Schools is cancelling all after school activities on Friday.

articles.title: Floods, droughts, then fires: Hydroclimate whiplash is speeding up globally
articles.author: Science Daily
articles.summary: Hydroclimate whiplash has already increased globally due to climate change, with further large increases expected as warming continues, according to a team of researchers. It's a rapid swings between intensely wet and dangerously dry weather, which is caused by climate change.

articles.title: Governor's climate team calls for disaster funds, environmental restoration in new report
articles.author: Savannah Harriman-Pote
articles.summary: Gov. Josh Green convened a six-person climate advisory team last summer to research disaster policies and release a report with recommendations ahead of the upcoming legislative session. According to the report, Hawaiʻi could see over $1 billion in property damage every year due to hurricanes, wildfires, floods and earthquakes. The Climate Team recommends the state put close to $2 billion into two separate funds for climate preparedness and disaster recovery.

articles.title: Great Lakes region's winters have shrunk by two or more weeks since 1995, study finds
articles.author: Milwaukee Journal Sentinel
articles.summary: Winters on the Great Lakes are getting shorter. Since 1995, winter has shortened by about 14 days and in some places close to three weeks. The study adds to mounting evidence that winter is the most rapidly changing season in the region, growing warmer and wetter with less snow. The biggest drop in winter days occurred in Lakes Superior and Erie, which has lost close to 3 weeks of winter. Lake Superior gained fall days and Lake Michigan gained spring days.

articles.title: Morning Mail: death toll warning as LA burns on, Dutton anti-union plan ‘illegal', Bluey's Lego deal
articles.author: Martin Farrer
articles.summary: The east coast is set for wet and wild weather in the coming week. Peter Dutton's promise to exclude the construction union from road projects could be illegal. Bluey is coming to a Lego box near you. Europe bought a record amount of liquefied natural gas from Russia last year.

articles.title: 2024 was the hottest year on record in South Korea
articles.author: Tatyana Kudrenok
articles.summary: The average annual temperature last year was 14.5 C, which is 2 C higher than the preceding 30-year average. It is highest in 52 years since nationwide weather observations began in 1973. The previous record for the hottest annual temperature was set just one year earlier in 2023, at 13.7 C. Rising sea surface temperatures are the main cause for last year's record-breaking annual temperature.

articles.title: La Niña Has Arrived—Here's What To Expect
articles.author: Ty Roush
articles.summary: A La Niña climate pattern has officially arrived, meteorologists said Thursday. It's the opposite of El Niño, which brought the warmest winter on record in the U.S. last year. It will probably be a weak event, but it has already produced wetter conditions in the Pacific Northwest and the Great Plains, drier conditions across the East Coast, Southwest and Northeast, and above-average temperatures in the Southwest and Mountain West.

articles.title: Study: Climate change means fewer freezing winter days in Michigan
articles.summary: According to Dahl, humanity is on track to add another 2 degrees Celsius of warming this century. The severity of human-caused thaw varies across the state, with Leelanau County experiencing the biggest impact. In general, the UP and inland northern Michigan have seen the smallest loss of wintry days due to climate change, while the Lower Peninsula shorelines have seen biggest. Washington, DC had the biggest loss of freezing days, at 12 annually. Hawaii, Florida and North Dakota had the smallest.

articles.title: Facing climate change Challenges
articles.author: damith
articles.summary: According to the United Nations Convention, climate change is a change of climate attributed directly or indirectly to human activity. Human activities have been the main contributor to climate change for around 1800 years. The emission of greenhouse gasses caused by human activities results in climate change. The world's average surface temperature is projected to exceed 3 degrees Celsius this century. Some parts of the world are expected to be even warmer. Sri Lanka is one of the most vulnerable countries in the global climate risk index. 74% of the natural disasters that took place in Sri Lanka during 1990 – 2018 were the result of climate change, including floods, landslides, storms, and droughts.

articles.title: It's Cold and Snowy: How Can There Be Global Warming?
articles.author: Eleanor Guerrero
articles.summary: According to NOAA, global temperatures have risen 1.5C above the long-term averages. The current increase in global average temperature is occurring faster than at any point in the last 11,000 years. Global warming is causing climate patterns to change, but it is only one aspect of climate change.

articles.title: Mark Steyn: Climate Hero
articles.author: James Delingpole
articles.summary: Mark Steyn has been fighting a lawsuit against Michael Mann for 13 years. Last night a DC Superior Court ruled in favor of Steyn and ordered Mann to pay $21,530 in attorney's fees and National Review costs. Mann is the creator of the infamous 'Hockey Stick' chart. Steyn wrote a book called Watermelons.

articles.title: Weak La Niña may influence U.S. weather until April, scientists predict
articles.author: Nonstop Local
articles.summary: La Niña has officially arrived in the Pacific Ocean. La Niña is weak and other atmospheric factors may also play a role in weather patterns. The Climate Prediction Center forecasts that La Niñas will persist through April, after which conditions are expected to return to neutral.

articles.title: 'No authority': Residents fed up with squalor in Camp Shortland bushland
articles.summary: The scrubland that divides Horseshoe Beach from Camp Shortland has become a hotbed of anti-social behaviour and squalour, Newcastle residents say. The encampent of tents has raised concerns for safety among beachgoers and vulnerable people living nearby.

articles.title: Boreal forests face increased wildfire threat as tree densities shift
articles.author: Phys Dot Org
articles.summary: The northern forests of Canada, Alaska and Siberia are about to change their tree density because of climate change, according to a new report.    “Climate change is changing the tree density in the northern forests’ of Canada and Alaska because of the climate change.

articles.title: LA's wildfires show climate change spares no one - not even the rich
articles.author: Diyora Shadijanova
articles.summary: The wildfires in Los Angeles have killed five people and displaced more than 100,000 people. High winds and severe drought have driven the most devastating winter wildfires in over 40 years in California. Since 2001, global forest fire emissions have risen by 60 per cent. The rich are among the biggest contributors to carbon dioxide emissions.

articles.title: La Niña Arrives: What Forecasters Predict of Climate Pattern
articles.author: Rachel Dobkin
articles.summary: La Niña, the periodic cooling of Pacific Ocean waters, has finally arrived. The previous La Niña concluded in 2023 after an abnormal three-year stretch. The exact cause of this year's late arrival has yet to be determined. La Niñas usually cause drier weather in the Southern and Western United States and wetter weather in parts of Indonesia, northern Australia and southern Africa.

articles.title: La Niña phenomenon expected to severely impact winter and spring of 2024-2025 in the United States
articles.author: Redação Mix Vale
articles.summary: The winter and spring of 2024-2025 in the United States are likely to be significantly influenced by the La Niña climatic phenomenon. This phenomenon is characterized by the cooling of surface waters in the equatorial Pacific Ocean. In the U.S., the expected effects include harsher winters in some regions, droughts in others, and significant changes in precipitation and temperature patterns. The impact on agriculture and the economy will be significant.

articles.title: Letters to the Editor: Readers in fire-weary Australia send their love to Los Angeles
articles.author: Los Angeles Times Opinion
articles.summary: To the editor, Rob Didcoe writes from Perth, Western Australia, where it's summer and they are in their own fire season. Rob's state is the most ravaged by fire in Australia. To Karen Ford, Melbourne, Australia, Rob's heart breaks for homeowners, residents and emergency firefighters.

articles.title: Flight path of Tasmanian boobook owls goes through wind farm zones in Bass Strait, study finds
articles.summary: Tasmanian boobooks, or mopoke, are migratory birds that migrate to the mainland. Monash University used GPS technology to track their journey between Victoria and Tasmania. The birds flew directly through two vast zones earmarked for large-scale offshore wind farms. Wind farms pose a significant risk to migratory bird species.

articles.title: The Geopolitical Race for Greenland's Resources Hidden Under the Ice
articles.author: Ed Foster
articles.summary: Greenland, the world's largest island, is often shrouded in mystery and intrigue. Under its icy surface lies a treasure trove of resources that has caught the attention of world powers. The geopolitical implications of Greenland's hidden wealth are profound and could reshape global energy and technology landscapes.

articles.title: SNAPPED: Great gray owl stare-down
articles.author: River Stingray
articles.summary: Nick Sulzer took photos of a great gray owl in Jackson, Wyoming. Great gray owls are the tallest owl in North America. Great grey owls can be difficult to spot as they blend in with their forest surroundings. They are a nomadic species with no regular migration pattern. They could be extinct in the continental U.S.

articles.title: Amber weather warning for ice brought in
articles.summary: A weather warning for ice has come into force on the Isle of Man. Road surface temperatures are expected to fall below freezing overnight. The whole Island is said to be at risk, but sheltered low-lying spots in central, southern and western parts are most likely to be affected. The weather warning will remain in place until 12pm tomorrow (10 January).

articles.title: Good Forest Managment Coming to Idaho But Not California
articles.author: Bill Colley
articles.summary: When wildfires were ravaging Idaho's central highlands last summer, liberals said it was due to man-made global warming. Now they blame Donald Trump for the fires scorching parts of California. They want to shift any responsibility from lefties like California Governor Gavin Newsom.

articles.title: La Nina climate pattern officially arrives and is expected to persist through winter
articles.author: Brian Donegan
articles.summary: NOAA's Climate Prediction Center announced Thursday that La Niña climate pattern officially arrived in December. Earth has been in an El Niño or neutral status since the spring of 2023. The CPC places the odds at 59% that LaNiña will persist through the three-month period spanning February-April 2025, but 60% chance for it to fade.

articles.title: California Wildfires Offer a Taste of the Problems Trump Faces
articles.author: Gord Magill
articles.summary: Donald Trump is going to be president in less than two weeks. He will have to deal with climate change-caused disasters during his second term. The 2024 hurricane season was the most destructive in U.S. history, causing an estimated $500 billion in damage to property, the economy and health. More than $800 billion in extra US health care costs each year can be attributed to climate and pollution.

articles.title: SINAC Issues Alert Over High Risk of Forest Fires in Costa Rica
articles.author: Tico Times
articles.summary: There is a risk of forest fires in various areas of Costa Rica due to the cold front impacting the country this week. The 2024 forest fire season was the most intense in the past decade, with 141 emergencies managed and 27,865 hectares scorched. The province most impacted was Guanacaste, with 92 fires.

articles.title: La Niña has officially started: What happens next?
articles.author: Nick Bannin
articles.summary: La Niña officially started in December 2024. La Niña is the cool phase of ENSO (El Niño-Southern Oscillation) that is marked by sea-surface water temperatures 0.5 degrees Celsius below the climatological average in a key area of the eastern Pacific. It has the greatest impact on the Northern Hemisphere in the winter season as the jet stream or storm track is pushed farther north, keeping it cooler in the Pacific Northwest and Upper Midwest. It's warmer and drier in the southern states.

articles.title: Birding: Annual Christmas Bird count results
articles.author: DR. MADELINE KALBACH
articles.summary: The Leadbetter Point Christmas Bird Count took place on Dec. 14. The CBC or Christmas Bird count in the Western hemisphere is administered by the National Audubon Society. The purpose of the count is to assess the population trends and distribution of birds in the area.

articles.title: 'Sobering' report issued on Hawaii natural disaster resilience spending needs
articles.author: Andrew Gomes
articles.summary: A panel advising Gov. Josh Green is urging the state Legislature to appropriate almost $2 billion over the next five years to help reduce and respond to future natural disaster damage in Hawaii. The suggested spending is tied to about a dozen recommendations made in a report produced by the advisory group. The team's top recommendation is to remove invasive plant species that provide fuel for wildfires.

articles.title: Fly the US flag at half-mast during Trump's inauguration
articles.author: Letters
articles.summary: When a US president dies, flags are lowered to half-mast for 30 days as a mark of respect. This will coincide with the second inauguration of President Trump, who has stated that "Nobody wants to see this, and no American can be happy about it".

articles.title: Why Greenland? Remote but resource-rich island occupies a key position in a warming world
articles.author: SETH BORENSTEIN
articles.summary: Greenland plays an outsized role in the daily weather experienced by billions of people and in the climate changes taking shape all over the world. It plays a big part in climate change.       in the article by Seth Borenstein.

articles.title: Intensifying climate whiplash set the stage for devastating California fires
articles.summary: There has been a dramatic shift from wet to dry weather in Southern California in the last two years. This phenomenon is called hydroclimate whiplash and is caused by human-caused climate change. With each additional degree of warming, the atmosphere absorbs and releases more water, leading to more intense floods and droughts.

articles.title: NOAA Says La Nina Ocean Cooling Has Finally Arrived, but It's Weak & May Cause Fewer Problems
articles.author: PTI
articles.summary: La Nina has finally appeared, but the periodic cooling of Pacific Ocean waters is weak and unlikely to cause as many weather problems as usual. La Nina is the flip side of the better-known El Nino and is an irregular rising of unusually cold water in a key part of the central equatorial Pacific that changes weather patterns worldwide. The last La Nina ended in 2023 after an unusual three-year stretch.

articles.title: Elusive La Nina Makes a Subtle Entrance: What It Means Globally
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: The arrival of La Nina has finally been confirmed. It is characterised by colder than usual water temperatures in the central equatorial Pacific. Historically, La Nina correlates with drier conditions in America's south and west, and increased wet weather in parts of Indonesia and Australia. It also impacts hurricane activity during summer.

articles.title: Climate and environment updates: How global warming is making climate more volatile
articles.summary: The ABC News Climate and Weather Unit is cutting through the noise by curating what you need to know to keep the people and places you care about safe. New research published in Nature Reviews Earth & Environment and the Fifth National Climate Assessment focuses specifically on hydroclimate volatility. President Joe Biden is taking executive action to ban oil and gas.

articles.title: A major climate pattern shift has finally happened. Will it change our weather?
articles.author: Doyle Rice
articles.summary: La Niña has finally developed, but it's a weak climate pattern. It's expected to last until the spring of 2025. The rest of the winter is expected to be dry and wet in the southern U.S. and wetter in the Pacific Northwest.

articles.title: A Climate Method in Trump's Greenland Madness
articles.author: Karl Mathiesen
articles.summary: The climate skeptic is responding to the reality of the Arctic's melting ice. He wants more resource extraction, faster trade routes and new military bases, among other things.      .   i   for confidential support call the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline on 1-800-273-8255.

articles.title: Scientists prize neutrality – that doesn't cut it any more. In 2025, they must fully back the climate movement
articles.author: Bill Mcguire
articles.summary: Last year was the first time that the global average temperature exceeded 1.5C above preindustrial times over a calendar year. One of the scientists was jailed for five years for organising protests to block a motorway. The other was not allowed to provide expert testimony about the potential damage of climate breakdown during the court case. The establishment and vested interests are trying to shut down voices seeking to tell the truth about our dire predicament. There are nearly 9 million scientists in the world, making up a tribe that is one of the most trusted groups on the planet. They need to mobilise together to demand that leaders treat climate breakdown as an emergency and act accordingly.

articles.title: Climate: Whanganui warmer than average in 2024 as slow trend upward continues
articles.author: Multimedia Journalist
articles.summary: Whanganui was warmer than average last year. The mean maximum temperature was 18.9C, the fourth-highest since records began in 1937. Last year was New Zealand's 10th warmest on record. The national average temperature for 2024 was 13.25C, just over 0.5C above the 1991-2020 average.

articles.title: Weak La Nina Emerges, Minimal Weather Impact Expected
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: The La Nina phenomenon has made its arrival. It is the counterpart to El Nino phenomenon. Its effects are usually significant, but this event is expected to be milder. The delay in La Nina's emergence is likely linked to the overall warming of the world's oceans in recent years.

articles.title: Intensifying climate whiplash set the stage for devastating California fires
articles.author: Ian James
articles.summary: There was a dramatic shift from wet to dry weather in Southern California in the last two years. This phenomenon is called hydroclimate whiplash and it's caused by human-caused climate change. It's already increased 31% to 66% since the mid-1900s. It will more than double if the world reaches 3 degrees C or 5 degrees F of warming.

articles.title: La Niña emerges in Pacific triggering global weather changes
articles.author: Brian K. Sullivan
articles.summary: After months of anticipation, La Niña has finally emerged. Ocean surface temperatures dropped to 0.9F of a degree (0.5C) below normal across the parts of the Pacific tracked by the US. The phenomenon can raise drought risk in agricultural areas of Argentina and Brazil and bring heavier rainfall across parts of Indonesia and northern Australia.

articles.title: NOAA says La Nina ocean cooling has finally arrived, but it's weak and may cause fewer problems
articles.author: Seth Borenstein
articles.summary: NOAA says La Nina ocean cooling has finally arrived, but it's weak and may cause fewer problems than usual. La Nina is the flip side of the better-known El Nino and is an irregular rising of unusually cold water in a key part of the central equatorial Pacific that changes weather patterns worldwide. The last La Nina ended in 2023 after an unusual three-year stretch.

articles.title: New Zealand to have more rainy, windy days under La Nina impact
articles.author: Source: Xinhua
articles.summary: New Zealand will have more rainy and windy days from January to March this year under potential La Nina impact. La Nina usually forms in winter, peaks in late spring, and then gradually weakens through summer. It is only the second time in 75 years that a La Nina onset has arrived in summer.

articles.title: Climate Minute Antarctic Sea Ice Recovery
articles.author: Lawyer Lisa
articles.summary: Antarctic sea ice extent recovered to 7.3 million sq km by the end of 2024. Mainstream media did not report it. It was close to the 1981 to 2010 average extent. It will be about the same by December 2024, as it was in 1981.

articles.title: 1.2-million-year-old ice pulled up from under Antarctica
articles.author: Popular Science
articles.summary: A newly uncovered Antarctic ice core represents the oldest known ice on the planet. The ice core was recovered from over 9,000 feet (2,800 meters) deep underground, where the Antarctic ice sheet meets bedrock. This is the longest continuous record of our past climate from an ice core.

articles.title: Winter's brushstroke on Xiangshawan Desert in China's Inner Mongolia
articles.author: Source: Xinhua
articles.summary: Ordos Xiangshawan Desert in Inner Mongolia, China, is covered in snow and windblown dunes. An aerial view of the desert gives it a stunning new appearance.    - i.e. as snowflakes gently descend and the winds sweep across the dunes, the desert takes on a new look.

articles.title: Scientists drill nearly 2 miles down to pull million-year-old ice from Antarctic
articles.author: PAOLO SANTALUCIA
articles.summary: The ice core is at least 1.2 million years old. It is expected to show how Earth's atmosphere and climate have evolved. It will also provide insight into how Ice Age cycles have changed and help in understanding how atmospheric carbon changed climate, scientists say.

articles.title: After finish of hurricane debris removal process, Lee County announces waste guidelines
articles.author: Staff Report
articles.summary: After finish of hurricane debris removal process, Lee County announces waste guidelines for January 9, 2025. Debris collection for Hurricane Milton has concluded for unincorporated areas of Lee County. Collections on the sparsely populated islands of Upper Captiva, Useppa and Cayo Costa are ongoing.

articles.title: 1.2-million-year-old ice pulled up from under Antarctica
articles.author: Laura Baisas
articles.summary: A newly discovered Antarctic ice core is 1.2 million years old. It is the oldest known ice on the planet. It was recovered from over 9,000 feet (2,800 meters) deep underground near the Concordia Research Station in southeastern Antarctica. It preserved a record of Earth's climate history, continuous information on atmospheric temperatures and some clear samples of old air with greenhouse gases.

articles.title: ‘The weather is going to be mixed'
articles.summary: Niwa principal forecaster Chris Brandolino says the weather is going to be mixed over the next three months. There is an increased likelihood of more westerly winds interspersed with easterly air flows. The rest of New Zealand has about equal chances for near normal or above normal rainfall for the coming 3 months.

articles.title: Temps in SWFL plummet as cold front moves through
articles.author: Andrew West
articles.summary: Temps in SWFL plummet as cold front moves through. The vegetables are grown for the Community Cooperative food bank in Lakes Park Community Garden in Fort Myers on Thursday, Jan. 9, 2025. A pedestrian braves cool temperatures while on a stroll at Lakes Park, Fort Myers.

articles.title: Shared heat tolerance leaves ecosystems at risk of sudden climate-driven collapse
articles.author: Joseph Williamson
articles.summary: Last year, much of the world's largest coral reef system was transformed into a white boneyard due to climate change. Many species that live together share remarkably similar thermal limits. Species living in the same places tend to have similar tolerances, warning of abrupt losses of biodiversity in the decades to come.

articles.title: Species reach their heat limits at similar temperatures, leaving ecosystems at risk of sudden climate-driven collapse
articles.author: Joseph Williamson
articles.summary: Last year, much of the world's largest coral reef system was transformed into a white boneyard due to climate change. Many species that live together share remarkably similar thermal limits. Species living in the same places tend to have similar tolerances, warning of abrupt losses of biodiversity in the decades to come.

articles.title: NOAA says La Nina ocean cooling has finally arrived, but it's weak and may cause fewer problems
articles.author: SETH BORENSTEIN
articles.summary: A La Nina has finally appeared. It's the flip side of the better-known El Nino. La Nina is the periodic cooling of Pacific Ocean waters. The last La Nina ended in 2023 after an unusual three-year stretch. La Ninas tend to cause drier weather in the South and West of the United States and wetter weather in Indonesia, northern Australia and southern Africa.

articles.title: NOAA says La Nina ocean cooling has finally arrived, but it's weak and may cause fewer problems
articles.author: Seth Borenstein
articles.summary: The long-awaited La Nina has finally appeared, but it is weak and unlikely to cause as many weather problems as usual. La Nina is the flip side of the better-known El Nino, which is an irregular rising of unusually cold water in a key part of the central equatorial Pacific Ocean. The last La Nina ended in 2023 after an unusual three-year stretch.

articles.title: NOAA says La Nina ocean cooling has finally arrived, but it's weak and may cause fewer problems
articles.author: SETH BORENSTEIN
articles.summary: La Nina has finally appeared, but it's weak and unlikely to cause many weather problems. La Nina is the flip side of the better-known El Nino. It's an irregular rising of unusually cold water in the central equatorial Pacific that changes weather patterns worldwide.

articles.title: Why are there more California fires in January this year?
articles.author: Internewscast
articles.summary: Southern California is experiencing its most devastating winter fires in more than four decades. AccuWeather estimated damage from the latest fires could reach $57 billion. There is a clear link between climate change and more frequent dry falls and winters that provide fuel for fires.

Understanding volcanic eruptions could help prepare the world for the next one.

articles.title: Tasmanian senator Jacqui Lambie's call to arms for young Aussies to volunteer
articles.author: Jessica Wang
articles.summary: Jacqui Lambie is calling on young people to volunteer in the aftermath of natural disasters due to climate change. She is also chairing a committee into establishing a National Volunteer Incentive Scheme (Climate Army). The committee is accepting submissions until February 25 and will report to parliament by September 22.

articles.title: Tasmanian senator Jacqui Lambie's call to arms for young Aussies to volunteer
articles.author: Jessica Wang
articles.summary: Jacqui Lambie is calling on young people to volunteer in the aftermath of natural disasters due to climate change. She is chairing a committee into establishing a National Volunteer Incentive Scheme (Climate Army). The committee will report to parliament by September 22. Volunteering among people aged between 18 and 24 years of age fell from 36.5% in 2019 to 25% in April 2022.

articles.title: Antarctic sea ice rebounds from record lows
articles.author: Dawn
articles.summary: Antarctic sea ice rebounded in December after a long period of record lows. The rate of sea ice loss during the warmer spring months of November and December slowed to well below average, according to scientists from the US.       "There was a very long period to near-record daily lows"

articles.title: Hern says he'll 'look at' Trump plans for Greenland, Panama Canal
articles.author: Tulsa World
articles.summary: Hern says the president-elect is concerned that China is essentially operating the canal. Observers say climate change is a factor in the canal management dispute. There is renewed interest in Greenland, according to Hern. Hern is concerned about China's control of the canal and climate change.

articles.title: What does climate change have to do with California's fires?
articles.author: system
articles.summary: There are signs climate change is already reshaping fire seasons around the world, experts say. Los Angeles is currently battling catastrophic wildfires due to climate change, which is increasing the risk of wildfires.    for the world. articles.author: News18
articles.summary: India has recorded five of its warmest years in the last 15 years. There have been record-breaking heatwave spells and torrential rains in the past few years. It was 2024, 2016, 2009, 2010, 2010 and 2017. It has also been warm in some other years as well.

articles.author: The Tribune San Luis Obispo
articles.summary: The intensity of the winds and the dry conditions are leading to more wintertime blazes, one expert said.      Â  .   "The intensity and dry conditions" are causing more blazes in the wintertime, according to experts.

articles.summary: Experts say Australia can no longer rely on northern hemisphere nations for water bombing aircraft and firefighters during the summer because it's no longer safe.    for water-bombing aircraft and firefighting during the winter.  i.e. Northern Hemisphere nations no longer provide water bombing.

articles.author: Israel National News
articles.summary: The decision follows the rise in antisemitic attacks across Australia. Jewish organizations are critical of the decision.   in response to the increase in anti-Semitic attacks in Australia and the rise of anti-semitic incidents.  in Australia. in the UK.

articles.title: Weather: La Ni�a watch in place for the second time in 75 years
articles.author: RNZ
articles.summary: This summer is going to be wetter and windier than usual due to a change in air flow patterns. La Niña watch will remain in place until March due to the cooling of the tropical Pacific. NIWA's seasonal climate outlook is from January through to March.

articles.title: Government mismanagement, not climate change, is to blame for California's destructive wildfires
articles.author: Fox News
articles.summary: It's fire season again in California and politicians are blaming the extent of the fires on climate change. Sen. Bernie Sanders' X account mentions that it's been eight months since the area has seen rain and the scale of damage and loss is similar to two years ago.

articles.title: Veganuary: Skip the meat and dairy to help reduce global warming
articles.author: Independent online
articles.summary: Scientists warn that if we don't change our eating habits and our addiction to animal products, we won't be able to avoid dangerous levels of global warming. Meat and dairy farming contribute 14.5% of all greenhouse gas emissions which are causing global warming, according to the environmental news.

articles.title: Wind, warmth and drought fuelled LA fires, scientists say
articles.author: RTE
articles.summary: Scientists say the California wildfires are the latest in climate-fuelled weather extremes that are likely to escalate further as global temperatures continue to climb. The blazes are erupting well outside of the traditional wildfire season and are spreading quickly. Climate change is reshaping the characteristic patterns of wildfire in a region.

articles.title: La Niña emerges in Pacific triggering global weather changes
articles.author: Brian K. Sullivan
articles.summary: A weather-changing La Niña has developed in the equatorial Pacific, adding to drought worries in California and the southern US, as well as the croplands in South America. Ocean surface temperatures have risen due to higher than normal sea surface temperatures.

articles.title: Greta A. Freeland
articles.author: The People's Defender
articles.summary: Greta A. Freeland, 73, passed away on Sunday, December 29, 2024. Greta was born February 3, 1951 in Cherry Fork, Ohio, and she was 73 years old at the time of her death. She was a resident of Cherry Fork.

articles.title: Beach turf wars are dividing Australia
articles.author: The Spectator
articles.summary: Donald Trump threatens to annex Greenland and the Panama Canal. China is flexing its military and economic muscles. Britain is in a state of political crisis. Los Angeles tragically burns. There are conflicts in Ukraine and the Middle East. Here in Australia, there is only one issue.

articles.title: 'Flooding trapped me in my house'
articles.author: BBC News
articles.summary: The Gardeners' World presenter has seen flooding get worse and worse over the past 30 years and he's seen it get worse. He's seen a rise in the number of people affected by the flooding. He has also seen a decrease in the amount of rain.

articles.title: EDITORIAL: Small actions by individuals add up in battle with climate change
articles.author: Asahi News
articles.summary: The world is experiencing a surge of extreme weather events, including heat waves, droughts and floods. The United Nations warns that climate change is not 'a global problem' but 'your crisis' and we need to act now. Gusuko Budori no Denki:

articles.author: Public Technologies
articles.summary: The world is getting hotter, resulting in severe hurricanes, thunderstorms and floods in the near future, says Boy_Anupong from Media Relations Media Information and Corporate News Media Information 2025 to 2024. The world will be more prone to natural disasters in the future.

articles.title: California wildfires fuelled by months of unusual extreme weather
articles.author: New Scientist
articles.summary: Fast-moving wildfires are burning long after the regular fire season is over due to an unlikely sequence of extreme weather events. Climate change may be to blame for the unusual weather events, which may have been exacerbated by climate change, according to some scientists.

articles.author: BBC News
articles.summary: Farmer is worried more crashes will happen on the same road as the cold snap continues as he is worried about the number of accidents on the road as a result of the cold weather continues to get worse. He is concerned about the safety of the road and people using it.

articles.title: Snail shells change colour to cope with hotter city climates
articles.author: The Times/The Sunday Times
articles.summary: Cities are often hotter than the surrounding countryside due to the urban heat island effect. The heat of cities is also helping to drive people to drive more.   .      in urban areas there is less vegetation to help cool the air.

articles.title: Bernie Sanders Blames Raging California Wildfires on Climate Change
articles.author: Breitbart
articles.summary: Bernie Sanders is blaming the raging California wildfires on climate change. The wildfires are caused by climate change, according to Sanders. The cause of the California wildfires is not yet known, but is believed to be related to global warming, as Sanders claims.

articles.title: ‘Silent killer': How heat stress can affect mental health in workers
articles.author: The Philadelphia Inquirer
articles.summary: Mental health is a less visible sign of heat stress than physical stress. People in Southeast Asia should pay attention to the impact of heat on mental health as the world warms, experts at a heat conference warned. Many people are not aware that they are being affected by heat stress.

articles.title: The dangerous combination fueling the L.A. fires: Exceptional dryness and strong winds
articles.author: Yahoo Daily News
articles.summary: Drought, an exceptionally dry winter and powerful Santa Ana winds are to blame for California's drought and dry weather.       in the U.S. there is a long-term drought and a short-term dry winter due to the Santa Ana wind.

articles.title: Climate News to Watch in 2025
articles.author: Who What Why
articles.summary: 2014 was Earth's hottest year on record by a wide margin. Human-caused climate-warming pollution and atmospheric greenhouse gas concentrations reached new levels. There are some provisions in the law that have helped overall, but you need to use a scalpel and not a sledgehammer.

articles.title: La Niña has arrived. Here's what that means.
articles.author: Scott Dance
articles.summary: La Niña is the opposite of El Niño and is known for cooling a vast swath of the Pacific Ocean. It is forecast to be short-lived, with about a 3-in-5 chance that it persists through April and similar chances that so-called neutral conditions return sometime between March and May. La Niña arrives as the planet experiences persistent temperatures that are the hottest in more than 100,000 years.

articles.title: What is our climate vision for the NDCs?
articles.author: Soha Nisar
articles.summary: Pakistan's ability to translate its climate change goals into meaningful action will determine whether the country can rise to the challenge or be swept away by the tides of ecological disaster. Pakistan has committed to reducing its greenhouse gas emissions by 60 per cent by 2030, with 35 per cent of this target contingent on international financial support. The energy sector is the largest contributor to Pakistan's carbon emissions. The government's commitment to phasing out coal imports is a step in the right direction, but it must be followed by decisive action.

articles.title: Unignorable
articles.author: News Desk
articles.summary: Climate change in Pakistan is affecting our health, economy, and future. Efforts like planting trees and creating pro-environment policies are good steps, but they are not enough. Pakistan needs to adopt renewable energy, protect forests, and prepare for disasters. Pakistan also needs to stand firm on the global stage, demanding support and resources to combat this crisis.

articles.title: Antarctic sea ice rebounds from record lows: US scientists
articles.author: AFP
articles.summary: Antarctic sea ice extent has recovered to 7.3 million square kilometres by the end of 2024, close to the 1981 to 2010 average. Scientists have been concerned since mid-2016 that global warming could be setting in motion more lasting changes in how much sea ice forms around the world's coldest continent.

articles.title: A chilly morning prompts bundling up
articles.author: THE BRUNSWICK NEWS
articles.summary: Justin Brown wore a knit cap with ear flaps and a camouflage face covering as he worked the golf cart stand at the Jekyll Island Golf Club Wednesday morning. The temperature remained below 40 degrees until around 9:30 a.m. in the Golden Isles.

articles.title: New Oregon climate assessment documents continued warming and signs of adaptation
articles.author: Michelle Klampe
articles.summary: Oregon's annual average temperature increased by 2.2 degrees Fahrenheit over the last century and is likely to become as much as 5 degrees Fahrenheit warmer by 2074. Snowfall is projected to decrease by 50% by 2100, and more precipitation will fall as rain. Businesses in Oregon are adapting to climate change, including B Corporation-certified wineries.

articles.title: MARTIN: Counting down to spring, Neil Young's vault and could this be Iron Maiden's last tour?
articles.author: Dale Martin
articles.summary: There are 70 more days until March 20. I hate cold weather. If I ever win the lottery, I'm moving to the equator. There is an average daily temperature of 88 degrees and over 2000 hours of sunshine per year there.

articles.title: Climate change: No going back
articles.author: 李潇阳
articles.summary: 2024 is expected to be the warmest year on record. Last year witnessed severe droughts in much of South America, southern Africa, the Zambezi basin, the Mediterranean and eastern Europe. Warm oceans fuel more powerful hurricanes and typhoons. 6.6 million people were displaced in 2023 alone due to floods, storms, drought, and wildfires. Between 1970 and 2021, 11,778 disasters attributed to weather events and water extremes caused 2.1 million deaths and $4.3 trillion in economic losses.
